item.title: Calculus - Multi-dimensions
item.description:
WHY: Why should we learn calculus in multi-dimensions?

More applicable in the real world.

WHAT: What is function in Multi-dimension

  • Express: $f(x, y, z, \ldots)$

  • Visualize

    • Domain & range
    • Graphs: Level curves

WHAT: What is differentiation - Partial Derivatives

WHY: Limit & Continuity - Differentiable

  • Limit

    $$ \lim_{(x, y) \rightarrow (a, b)}f(x, y) = L $$

    When $f \rightarrow L$ no matter what direction $(x, y) \rightarrow (a, b)$, the limit of $f$ in $(a, b)$ exists.

    If $f(x, y) \rightarrow L_1$ as $(x, y) \rightarrow (a, b)$ along a path $C_1$ and $f(x, y) \rightarrow L_2$ as $(x, y) \rightarrow (a, b)$ along a path $C_2$, where $L_1 \neq L_2$, then $\lim_{(x, y) \rightarrow (a, b)}f(x, y)$ does not exist.

    • Limit along axis: let $y = 0$ or $x = 0$
    • Limit along specific line: $y = x$

  • Continuity: $\lim_{(x, y) \rightarrow (a, b)}f(x, y) = f(a, b)$

WHAT: What is Partial Derivatives

  • Algebra: Definition $$ \frac{\partial}{\partial x}f = f_x(a, b) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{f(a + h, b) - f(a, b)}{h} = g’(a) \ (g(x) = g(x, b)) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{g(a + h) - g(a)}{h} $$ $$ \frac{\partial}{\partial y}f = f_y(a, b) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{f(a, b + h) - f(a, b)}{h} = g’(b) \ (g(y) = g(a, y)) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0}\frac{g(b + h) - g(b)}{h} $$

    • Differentiable: $\Delta{z} = f_x(a, b)\Delta{x} + f_y(a, b)\Delta{y} + \epsilon_1\Delta{x} + \epsilon_2\Delta{y}, (\epsilon_1, \epsilon_2) \rightarrow (0, 0) \Rightarrow (\Delta{x}, \Delta{y}) \rightarrow (0, 0)$
    • Differentials: $dz = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} dx + \frac{\partial z}{\partial y} dy$

  • Geometry: Tangent Planes $$ A(x - x_0) + B(y - y_0) + C(z - z_0) = 0 \Rightarrow z - z_0 = f_x(x_0, y_0)(x - x_0) + f_y(x_0, y_0)(y - y_0) $$

    • Linear Approximations

HOW: How to do Partial Derivatives

  • Chain Rule $$ (1) \frac{dz}{dt} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} \frac{dx}{dt} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \frac{dy}{dt} $$ $$ (2) \frac{\partial z}{\partial s} = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} \frac{\partial x}{\partial s} + \frac{\partial z}{\partial y} \frac{\partial y}{\partial s}, \frac{\partial z}{\partial s} = \frac{\partial z}{\partial x} \frac{\partial x}{\partial s} + \frac{\partial z}{\partial y} \frac{\partial y}{\partial s} $$ $$ (3) General: \frac{\partial u}{\partial t_i} = \frac{\partial u}{\partial x_1} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial t_i} + \frac{\partial u}{\partial x_2} \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial t_i} + \frac{\partial u}{\partial x_3} \frac{\partial x_3}{\partial t_i} + \ldots $$

HOW: How to Apply to Vector

$$ D_u{f(x, y)} = \nabla{f(x, y)} \cdot \vec{u} $$

  • $D_u{f(x, y)} = \vec{P’Q’}$ - Gradient Vector: moving in a tangent plant with a specific direction
    • $\nabla{f(x, y)}$ represents tangent plant: $\nabla = \hat{i}\frac{\partial}{\partial x} + \hat{j}\frac{\partial}{\partial y} + \hat{k}\frac{\partial}{\partial z} + \ldots$
      • $\text{div } f = \nabla{f} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}\hat{i} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\hat{j} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial z}\hat{k}$
      • $\text{curl } \vec{F} = \nabla \times \vec{F} = \begin{vmatrix} \hat{i} & \hat{j} & \vec{k} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ P & Q & R \end{vmatrix} = (\frac{\partial R}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial Q}{\partial z})\hat{i} + (\frac{\partial P}{\partial z} - \frac{\partial R}{\partial x})\hat{j} + (\frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial y})\hat{k}$
      • $\text{div curl } \textbf{F} = 0$
    • $\vec{u}$ represents a direction (in unit), or $\vec{u} = \langle \hat{a}, \hat{b} \rangle$

HOW: How to Apply to Finding Maximum and Minimum

  • SECOND DERIVATIVES TEST

HOW: LAGRANGE MULTIPLIERS

WHAT: What is integral - Multiple Integrals

WHAT: What is double integral

$$ \iint\limits_R{f(x, y)}dA = \lim_{max \Delta x_i, \Delta y_i \rightarrow 0}\sum_{i = 1}^{m}\sum_{j = 1}^{n}f(x_{ij}^* , y_{ij}^* ) \Delta A_{i,j}(Double \ Riemann \ Sum, Midpoint: x^* , y^ * \rightarrow \bar{x}, \bar{y}) $$

HOW: How to calculate iterated integrals?

$$ \int_a^b\int_c^d{f(x, y)}dA = \int_a^b[\int_c^df(x, y)dy]dx = \int_c^d[\int_a^bf(x, y)dx]dy $$

HOW: How to apply to reality

Volume

Region of $x_1, x_2, y_1(x), y_2(x), Assume \ x_1 \leq x_2, y_1 \leq y_2$:

$$ V = \int_{y_1(x)}^{y_2(x)}\int_{x_1}^{x_2}f(x, y)dA = \int_{x_1}^{x_2}[\int_{y_1(x)}^{y_2(x)}f(x, y)dy]dx$$

HOW: How to apply to Vector Calculus

WHAT: What is Fields

  • Vector Fields: $\vec{F}(x, y) = I(x, y)\hat{i} + J(x, y)\hat{j} = \langle I(x, y), J(x, y) \rangle (in \ \R^2)$

  • Gradient Fields: $\nabla{f(x, y)} = f_x(x, y)\hat{i} + f_y(x, y)\hat{j}$

HOW: How to integrate along the line - Line Integrals

$$ \int_{curve \ C}f(x, y)ds = \lim_{\max \Delta{s}_i \rightarrow 0}\sum_{i = 1}^{n}f(x_i^* , y_i^*)\Delta{s}_i, curve \ C: s = \int_a^b\sqrt{(\frac{dx}{dt})^2 + (\frac{dy}{dt})^2}dt $$ $$ \Rightarrow \int_C f(x, y)ds = \int_a^b f(x(t), y(t))\sqrt{(\frac{dx}{dt})^2 + (\frac{dy}{dt})^2}dt $$

  • Vector Fields $$ W = \int_C \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r} = \int_a^b{\vec{F}(\vec{r}(t)) \cdot \vec{r’}(t)dt} \ (Substitution: \vec{r}(t) = \vec{r}) = \int_C \vec{F} \cdot \vec{T} ds $$

  • Conservative $$ F(x, y) = P\hat{i} + Q\hat{j}, F \text{ is conservative} \Leftrightarrow \frac{\partial P}{\partial y} = \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} \text{ thoughout } D $$

    • independent of path: $\int_C \vec{F} \cdot d \vec{r} \text{ is independent of path} \in D \Leftrightarrow \forall C \in D, \int_C \vec{F} \cdot d \vec{r} = 0$
      • $C$: Closed Path - its terminal point coincides with its initial point
    • conservative vector field: $\int_C \vec{F} \cdot d \vec{r} \text{ is independent of path} \in D \Leftrightarrow F \text{ is a conservative vector field}$ ($\nabla{f} = F$)

  • Relationship with double integral: Green’s Theorem $$ \oint_C \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r} = \oint_C P dx + Q dy = \iint_D(\frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial P}{\partial y})dA = \int_{\partial D}{P dx + Q dy} $$

    • Positive orientation: a simple closed curve $C$ refers to a single counterclockwise traversal of $C$
    • $\oint_C P dx = \oint_{g_2(x)}^{g_1(x)} P dx = - \oint_{g_1(x)}^{g_2(x)} P dx = -\int_{g_1(x)}^{g_2(x)} \int_a^b \frac{\partial P}{\partial y} dy dx = \iint_D(-\frac{\partial P}{\partial y}) dA$

HOW: How to integral with Surface

  • Parametric Surface: $\vec{r}(u, v) = x(u, v)\hat{i} + y(u, v)\hat{j} + z(u, v)\hat{k}$
    • Surfaces of Revolution: $x = x, y = f(x)\cos\theta, z = f(x)\sin\theta$
    • Tangent Planes: $\vec{r}_v = \frac{\partial x(u, v)}{\partial v}\hat{i} + \frac{\partial y(u, v)}{\partial v}\hat{j} + \frac{\partial z(u, v)}{\partial v}\hat{k}$
    • Surface Area: $A(S) = \iint_D |\vec{r}_u \times \vec{r}_v|dA$
    • Integral Along the Surface: Stokes’ Theorem - $\int_C \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r} = \iint_S \text{curl} \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{S}$
